awd_abstract_narration:
In humans, the sense of touch is closely linked with hand movements. An open question in neuroscience is how the brain combines touch signals (sensory) with hand movements (motor) to create a unified tactile perception of an object. Because of difficulties in studying how the human brain combines these cues, researchers study rats, which use ~60 whiskers to tactually explore the environment. The whisker system is an excellent model to investigate how neurons represent and unify touch and movement, but neuroscientists currently struggle to stimulate the whiskers in a way that imitates the signals obtained during natural exploratory behavior. In this proposal, the investigators will characterize naturalistic patterns of tactile input that the rat's brain evolved to process, and will develop new mathematical tools to describe the environmental features that the rat experiences. The proposed work is scientifically important for two reasons. First, because rodents are the most commonly used animals in neuroscience, these experiments will aid researchers studying many parts of the brain involved with touch and movement. Second, these new mathematical tools will help quantify the sense of touch across species, including humans. The proposed work will have significant broader impacts on science and mathematics education and public outreach. Undergraduate students will contribute to the work, and the investigators will lead Northwestern's Robotics Club to explore engineering applications of whisker-based tactile sensing. The investigators will also continue outreach efforts through the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers, the Society of Women Engineers, and Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry. 

In the fields of vision and audition, the receptive fields of central neurons are tuned to the statistics of the "natural scenes,- to those properties of the stimuli that the animal is likely to encounter in its natural environment. In the field of somatosensation it is challenging to quantify the natural tactile scene, in part because somatosensory signals are tightly linked to the animal's movements. The proposed work aims to begin to quantify the natural tactile scene for the rat vibrissal system by combining careful behavioral monitoring and simulations of rat head and whisker movements. The project has two major goals. The first is to characterize the statistics of the environments that the rat naturally inhabits. In Bayesian terms, this statistical distribution is called the "prior," because it describes the environment's geometrical features, unbiased by the tactile sampling choices of the animal. The second is to quantify the statistics of the environment sampled by the rat, given its choices of head motions and whisk cycle. In Bayesian terms, this statistical distribution is called the "posterior," because it incorporates the bias of the rat when preferentially sampling the tactile scene. This work is one of the first attempts to quantify the statistics of active touch, and it aims to make specific predictions for the receptive field properties that enable spatiotemporal integration. Equally important, this work will develop an appropriate mathematical framework for characterizing the geometry of natural scenes, an essential step towards describing active somatosensation using information theoretic measures.

por.por_cntn:
When you grasp a coffee mug or reach in your pocket for a coin, your sense of touch is closely linked to your hand movements. However, neuroscientists still do not fully understand how the brain combines sensory and movement information to allow you to perceive the mug or the coin. To study this question, this research project focused on the whisker system of rats and mice. These rodents use active, rhythmic movements of their whiskers for touch exploration, much in the same way that humans use their hands to explore their tactile environment. The whisker system is therefore a commonly used model to investigate how neurons represent and unify touch and movement.

The intellectual merit of this research project was threefold: it developed new methods to quantify the sense of touch across species, including humans; it advanced a comparative approach for studying whisker-based touch; and it improved our understanding of the coding and integrative properties expected in touch-sensitive neurons. Broader impacts of the work include training nine graduate students, developing a class on behavioral neuroscience, and offering research opportunities to over ten undergraduates and four high school students, even during the COVID pandemic. Finally, an unexpected but important outgrowth of the work was the development of a novel approach for improving clinical studies of facial nerve injury.

We started from the idea that touch-sensitive neurons will be most responsive to stimuli that an animal is likely to encounter in its natural environment. For example, a snake, a rat, and a human will use touch to explore an identical rock in very different ways. A snake will slide its body around the rock, a rat will explore with its snout and whiskers, and a human will use its hands. Neural processing for these animals is thus not only shaped by the properties of the rock itself, but also by how their sensors interact with the rock. Based on these ideas, we developed a mathematical framework to quantify the physical properties of objects – properties that are independent of the way that an animal explores them – and then developed approaches towards understanding how different animals explore objects through touch, particularly through their whisker arrays.

We took three-dimensional (3D) scans of natural and human-made objects to quantify their geometric properties (distance, slope, and curvature) at a scale of 1 cm2. High school students helped with initial scans. A neural model based on curvature – but not distance or slope – showed responses that resemble those observed in touch-sensitive regions of the primate brain (Zweifel, Solla, and Hartmann, in review). We performed a comparative analysis of vision, hearing, and touch to show that the way that the brain “cancels out” expected sensory information, so as to focus attention on more novel information, is likely different for touch sensing than for other senses (Zweifel and Hartmann, 2020).

We constructed an accurate 3D anatomical model of the rat’s face and whisker array (Belli et al., 2018) and took high speed video to quantify how rats coordinated head and whisker movements during touch exploration. By combining the 3D model with the video, we obtained a rich dataset to quantify the interplay between movement and touch. We anticipate these results will help scientists generate appropriate patterns of whisker stimulation during neurophysiological experiments. Undergraduate students helped train animals and analyze videos, leading to the development of a course on quantitative behavioral neuroscience. We also used the 3D model to simulate whisker sweeps across many objects and trained artificial neural networks to recognize these objects. We found that only a few types of networks achieved reasonable performance, suggesting the structure of biological networks that might sustain similar processing (Zhuang et al., 2017).

We compared the arrangement of facial sensory structures (eyes, ears, nostrils, mouth, and whiskers) across ten species of animals, ranging from rodents to pinnipeds. The touch signals transmitted by a whisker depend strongly on its geometric parameters, including its angles relative to the face and the way that it curves. Therefore, an important component of this work involved developing equations to describe similarities and differences in whisker shapes within and across species (Luo and Hartmann, in review).

We involved high school students in literature reviews aimed towards assessing whether the 3D tracking approaches developed in this project could be useful for studying animal models of human diseases (Considine et al., 2021). In collaboration with a clinician, we used 3D whisker tracking to help quantify and assess recovery of whisker movement in an animal model of facial nerve injury, a devastating and common clinical problem encountered in the field of otolaryngology. We anticipate continuing this work with clinicians to bring this approach more broadly into the field.
